The burden of proof is the responsibility of the person making the claim. If someone suggests that intelligent extraterrestrial life exists, and is visiting our planet, it is up to them to provide the evidence that supports their argument. You can not disprove a negative.
 
 Skeptic magazine provides a $1,000, 000 reward for anyone who can present irrefutable evidence for the existence of anything supernatural. Thus far, the reward has gone unclaimed. There is no reason to believe the claim made by so many crackpots.
 
 Of course, the chances weigh heavily in favor for the existence of other worlds, but nothing conclusive has been found to back up the claim that other intelligent life exists in the universe. Am I arrogant enough to believe that humans are the pinnacle of the evolutionary cycle, thus far? No. I hold the belief that there are other more advanced civilizations existing in the universe, but I doubt they have visited our planet, and question the possibility of such an anomaly.

Stormin, I'll assume you meant "you can't PROVE a negative". Obviously one can disprove a negative by showing the positive to be true. 
 "there's nothing in that box"
 "::opens box:: look, there's something"
 "oh"
 
 Anywho, it IS possible to prove a negative by showing that the positive is self-contradictory. For example, a square circle.
 
 As to the topic, I think there is some extraterrestrial life somewhere, but certainly don't think it has come here.

Crim,
 
 You are failing to see the difference between small-scale, verifiable negatives, like the empty box example, and large-scale unverifiable negatives, like the non-existence of god, or extraterrestrial life somewhere in the universe. David Hume is the philosopher who first articulated the idea that you can't prove a large-scale unverifiable negative. Given our knowledge of the universe and our lack of the ability to gather information about life-forms in other systems, this is precisely the sort of logical fallacy Hume described. Hume saw a problem with making generalizations based on a limited number of observations. This is called Hume's problem, and is the basis for the claim that you can not prove or disprove an unverifiable negative.

It seems to me, since our universe is incredibly large, that it would almost be impossible to find another world that supported life. Here is an interesting equation used to describe the existence of intelligent life within the universe. It is called the Drake equation. It has its skeptics because it is based on probabilities and is purely an estimate, a particularly bad one at that. It follows:
 
 N = R*Fp*Ne*Fl*Fi*L
 
 N = # of civilizations with trackable emissions
 
 R = rate of formation of stars like our sun
 
 Fp = Solar systems with planets
 
 Here is where the numbers get a little fuzzy.
 
 Ne = # of earth like planets per system
 
 Fl = fraction of those planets where life evolves
 
 Fi = fraction of those where technology develops
 
 L = Lifetime of those civilizations
 
 As you can see, most of these variables can only be concocted on the basis of a guess. The validity of N rest solely on the probability of these variables. Therefore, the propagation of error involved in this calculation is large. I don't buy into this, but it does raise some questions. If the values for the given variables could be determined with some accuracy, it might provide a good correlative description. The problem with it is that they can't. Therefore, this equation is useless. Here is a link, if you would like to know more. I think you can get a general sense about the type of people who evoke Drake's equation as a basis for the belief in alien contact by looking at this website.

It is impossible to prove there is extra-terrestrial intelligent life somewhere out there at the present time, however, the chances are extremely high that there is. There are so many galaxies in the universe, each with loads of stars, lots with loads of planets, so chances are, there are some that can support life (eg. fossilized life on mars) which probably has evolved into intelligent life at the same time as there is intelligent life on Earth. Although, judging by the huge size of the universe, the chances are extremely small that any of these civilizations has visited earth yet. 
 
 (I bet that would sound even more intelligent if I didn't keep using that word so much ;) )

While I think there probably is some form of intelligent life out there, I seriously doubt they have ever visited earth. The only way I could see this happening is if they have somehow detected our prescence in the universe (our bubble of radio signals hasn't covered a large enough area for any intelligent life to intercept most likely), and were somehow able to travel faster than light--which as far as I've read is impossible. Either way, if we do discover life on another planet, it's either going to be far less advanced than us, or vastly more advanced.

 Perhaps.
 
 Let's do the math (not the republican part though).
 
 The milky way has a estimated 400 BILLION stars. Let's combine 100 galaxies to make this easier. 1/1000 of these stars have planets. 40 billion left. 1/1000 of them have planets capable of supporting life. 4 million left, 1/1,000 of them actually have life. 400 left, and 1/100 of them have sentient life. 4 from 40 trillion stars. Now, there are billions of other galaxies. Do the math. :)

 I made a crop circle once, myself and a few colleages got together one night and made one, it wasnt big or complicated, Its not as difficult as you think.
 
 Then we waited to see the reaction, it was all part of a local paper stunt to see how many people would fall for it, and there were loads of nuts. what i noticed was when i interviewed some people, they wanted it to be real, there were people who actually wanted it to be real. 
 
 Even after we revealed it was a hoax there were still people taking readings and studying the circles.

Here is an interesting equation used to describe the existence of intelligent life within the universe. It is called the Drake equation. It has its skeptics because it is based on probabilities and is purely an estimate, a particularly bad one at that. It follows:
 
 N = R*Fp*Ne*Fl*Fi*L
 
 N = # of civilizations with trackable emissions
 
 R = rate of formation of stars like our sun

 Here is where the numbers get a little fuzzy.
 
 Ne = # of earth like planets per system
 
 Fl = fraction of those planets where life evolves

 that equation is WAY too simplistic
 there are hypotheses that claim perhaps that the way the moon formed and the fact that we have tides contributed to the development of life on earth
 
 if something like this were true, and if the way our moon formed is a extremely rare, then life would indeed be a rare thing, since we are on a rocky planet in just the right zone of orbit for temperatures to support liquid water with just the right mix of certain ingredients, etc. with a moon that's way too large for the planet
 
 it all depends on what is required for life to form (which we are not sure, but we are pretty sure that liquid water is necessary, but that is only for organic life) and then how rare or common are those conditions in the universe
 
 these things we just don't know, we don't even know what percentage of stars support rocky planets, or how many gas giants have moons that could support life
